history.content: You do not need to take Math 54 for the EECS major. It sounds like you're planning to take this course for math department requirements (minor, course pre-reqs), so you will need to check with their staff.

Math major here. I've never taken EE 16A/B myself, but I can tell you that a strong linear algebra foundation is paramount to taking upper division Math courses. That being said, look through "Linear Algebra and Its Applications" by Lay and see if you're familiar with most of the concepts in that book. If you are, then I'm pretty sure you can get special permission to opt out of 54 for major/minor requirements with EE 16A/B (but ask the department, since this is just my speculations). Also, think of Math 110 and 104 as "pre-reqs" for most other upper div. Math courses (you'll need a strong background in more advanced lin. alg. and analysis).

Sequence-wise, I'd go 54 (if needed) -> 110, 128A -> 104 -> 113 -> 185. 113 and 104 are a decent amount of work, especially 104 if you're weak with proofs. 110, 128A are one of the easier/lighter ones. 185, I can't say since I haven't taken it yet.

=====

I want to add that my experience with 104 and 128A are the exact opposite as mentioned above, because this is largely due to professor/textbook variance. 104's difficulty depends heavily on which book your professor uses (Ross is the easier one while Rudin (?) is the more theoretical one), while 128A for me was a lot of busy-work. Relatively simple conceptually, but it was still a lot of work. 

=====

Just another data point - I know that EECS will allow you to replace any lower-division math "requirement" with an upper-div class if you fill out a yellow petition form. I would be surprised if that weren't an option for the math department.

children.subject:
Hello,

Is there any update on using EE 16A/B to wave the Math 54 requirement for a Math minor? I am also an EECS major interested in a math minor.

Thank you.

Just to expand on some of the previous answers, 16A/B should certainly prepare you for taking Math 110, and so if it's just a matter of taking the upper div math courses I don't think Math 54 is also something you have to take.  That said, if you want to major/minor in Math, officially Math 54 is still a requirement (we are talking with the math department about potentially accepting 16A/B instead - that's still in process and I don't know yet if it will work out), and there are certainly students who have taken Math 54 as well as 16A/B and felt like they benefitted from all of them (even though there is certainly a large degree of overlap, sometimes slightly different takes/perspectives can be useful).

@David Dinh Unless you take two separate math upper divs (110 and a separate diffeqs one), you won't be able to waive the 54 requirement, since 110 strictly covers only linear algebra. This was my scenario - I didn't want to take a diffeqs course, so I just went back to 54, talked with the professor, and took 2 units of Math 49 in parallel with the last 5 weeks of 54 to cover that requirement.

history.content: I'm going to be a freshman this fall and I'm currently enrolled in CS61A, EE16a, CS70, and Math 54. I have exempted math 1a/1b/53. I'm really interested in math and want to take upper div math classes, but it seems that Math 54 is a prereq for the upper div math classes like 110 and 104 and required for a math minor which I may be interested in. Apparently, however, ee16a/b cover almost all the material that math 54 covers. So I am asking do I still need to take 54? If not, what sequence of math classes should I take and when should I take them?
history.subject: Suggested route for EECS major interested in math
